p: The mVISTA results show that the cp genomes of Arnebia and Lithospermum possess relatively high diversity, with genic regions being more conserved than intergenic spacer regions, as is typical in angiosperm cp genomes ( Shaw et al., 2007; Huo et al., 2019; Song J. H. et al., 2019). Even though the cp genomes of A. guttata and A. tibetana displayed closer proximity than other cp genomes, trnS-GCU-trnG-UCC, trnC-GCA-petN, psaA-ycf3, trnI-CAU-ycf2, psbE-petL, clpP, and rps15-ycf1 regions were found to be hotspots of genetic variation ( Figure 4). Hotspot regions in plants indicate underlying evolution ( Morton and Clegg, 1993; Maier et al., 1995; Liu H. et al., 2018; Liu H. et al., 2019) and can be used to distinguish species or genera. Molecular markers relative to these regions serve for the identification of valuable herbal medicinal plants ( Cho et al., 2015; Hong et al., 2017; Park et al., 2018a, b). In terms of nucleotide diversity, most divergent regions were non-coding, which is again consistent with other cp genomes ( Schroeder et al., 2016; Zhitao et al., 2017; Liu E. et al., 2019; Smidt et al., 2020). Other cp genomes were reported to have highly variable non-coding regions at trnS-GCU-trnG-UCC, trnC-GCA-petN, psaA-ycf3, trnI-CAU-ycf2, psbE-petL, and rps15-ycf1. We noticed higher diversity in the atpB-rbcL region between A. guttata and A. tibetana compared to the other four species. This divergence indicated a species-unique region, which could be clearly distinguished and used for identification.
